table-wrap.anchoringText: The maximum number of WAG cycles is set to 15 because of the operator suggested strategy of 30 day water injection and 90 day CO2 injection phases. The time control method is allowed to eliminate a number of half cycles, but was not allowed to add cycles. All of the optimization parameters are kept the same (including the initial seed) and the producer BHPs are optimized during the process as well in all three cases. The results, as summarized in Table 1 and Figure 2, illustrate that the use of both rate and time controls for the injectors results in a higher objective function value by 13% when compared to rate control only. Contributing to the higher objective function (NPV), more oil is produced and less CO2 and water are injected when time controls were used.
table-wrap.label: Table 1
table-wrap.caption: Summary of the results for different optimized injection control strategies.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Summary of the results for different optimized injection control strategies.

table-wrap.anchoringText: The same geological model is used as in the deterministic experiments and both rate and time controls are optimized. The results of adding a value for CO2 storage can be seen in Table 2 where the NPV is increased by 35% over the original deterministic injection rate-and-time case and a total CO2 storage of 754000 tonnes is achieved, which is an increase of 246% over the original deterministic case. Figure 15 and Figure 16 show that the optimal strategy has changed in comparison to the deterministic case in Figure 5. As expected, significantly more CO2 is injected throughout the considered period.
table-wrap.label: Table 2
table-wrap.caption: Summary of results obtained with storage credits of 30 CAD per tonne included in the cost function and for constraints on the availability of CO2.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Summary of results obtained with storage credits of 30 CAD per tonne included in the cost function and for constraints on the availability of CO2.
